title: Espresso Cup, Concept Model, "Paper Porcelain", 2009
medium: Cut, scored, assembled cardboard, paper tape, applied pencil line
markings: "1" penciled on top of tab handle
provenance: 2014, acquired by Cooper-Hewitt directly from the designers.
creditline: Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund
description: Cylindrical cup with straight sides, squared D-shaped tab handle and tapered curved base. Cut and scored light gray cardboard; applied paper tape on body and underside; “1” penciled on top of tab handle
justification:
The Paper Porcelain series was originally conceived as a project to translate paper models – an integral part of Scholten & Baijings’s process – into porcelain. Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings started the process with their drawing, in which Scholten sketched the saucers and Baijings the cups, working out form, color, and geometry for the series. The designers then created the cut, folded, scored, and taped cardboard models, which were made into unglazed porcelain prototypes during a three-month residency at the European Ceramic Work Center in ‘s-Hertogenbosch (Den Bosch), The Netherlands. The cardboard models were first cast into polyurethane rubber molds in order to capture the surface texture of the cardboard. Plaster models were cast from these polyurethane rubber molds, followed by plaster production molds produced for the porcelain slip casting. 

Color is an important element in Scholten & Baijings’s work. To recreate the light grey, spotted color of the original cardboard, the designers developed a specific mix of glaze and porcelain to which they added metal drill dust to achieve the unique spots found in the cardboard. The paper tape used to bind the incised lines in the cardboard saucer models was recreated on the prototypes using glazes, which were color-tested to ensure they matched the original tape color. Pencil lines applied by hand to the porcelain prototypes emphasized the scored lines found on the cardboard models. The faceting and grid-like surface pattern of the Paper Porcelain series are elements seen across the designers’ work.

The Paper Table series, of which Paper Porcelain is a part, was awarded a Dutch Design Award in 2010 and a Wallpaper* Design Award in 2011.

tombstone.epitaph: Espresso Cup, Concept Model, "Paper Porcelain", 2009. Cut, scored, assembled cardboard, paper tape, applied pencil line. Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund. 2014-38-1.
